questions.question: A second year medical student attending his viva in the microbiology department, was asked to identify the given device and name any one item that can be sterilised by it. Which of the following options is correct?

options.A: Hot air oven and culture media

questions.explanation: Correct Answer : C) Hot air oven and glassware Explanation: The device in the given image is that of a hot air oven and it can be used to sterilise glassware . Hot air oven is a sterilisation method that works on the principle of dry heat . Dry heat causes its killing effect by protein denaturation , damage by oxidising molecules , destroying cell constituents and toxic effects of elevated levels of electrolytes. The items to be sterilised are kept inside the oven for 2 hours and a holding period of 160 o C . Sterilisation is achieved through direct conduction of heat to the items kept inside the oven. Items that can be sterilised are mainly glassware , metallic instruments ( both sharps and non sharps ), some heat-resistant oils and waxes that are immiscible in water such as dusting powder and liquid paraffin . Hot air oven Hot air oven and culture media (Option A) : The given image is that of a hot air oven but culture media in general cannot be sterilised by hot air oven . They are sterilised by autoclave (moist heat) and some culture media that contain egg like LJ media and serum like Loeffler’s serum slope are sterilised by inspissation . ( Options A, B and D ruled out ) Autoclave

questions.question: Match the following sterilisation techniques with their respective control methods. Sterilisation technique Control method 1. Hot air oven a. Bacillus pumilus 2. Autoclave b. Serratia marcescens 3. Membrane filtration c. Bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis spores 4.Ionizing Radiation d. Geobacillus stearothermophilus spores
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a Explanation: Sterilisation technique Control method 1. Hot air oven c. Bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis spores 2. Autoclave d. Geobacillus stearothermophilus spores 3. Membrane filtration b. Serratia marcescens 4.Ionizing Radiation a. Bacillus pumilus These control methods are biological indicators used to check the effectiveness of the sterilisation method. Spores of bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis are used as a control method for hot air ovens and ethylene oxide sterilisation (used mainly for heart-lung machines). Spores of geobacillus stearothermophilus are used as a control method for autoclave and plasma sterilisation . Bacillus globigi is also used as a control method for ethylene oxide sterilisation . Serratia marcescens and Brevundimonas diminuta are used as control methods for membrane filters . Reference: 1. Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 30-32 2. Essentials of Medical Microbiology- Apurba S Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page 22, 254-257

questions.question: During a community health meeting, a health inspector discusses the importance of preventing consumption of raw milk from cattle. What is the false statement regarding the treatment process of raw milk before consumption?

options.A: It is a type of disinfection method that uses moist heat.
options.B: Holder method is used to disinfect milk from Coxiella burnetii.
options.C: Presence of the enzyme phosphatase in the milk post-treatment suggests inadequate efficacy.
options.D: It helps to extend the shelf life of milk.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Holder method is used to disinfect milk from Coxiella burnetii. Explanation: The treatment process of raw milk discussed is pasteurisation and the method used to disinfect milk from Coxiella burnetii is Flash method and not Holder method. Pasteurisation is a moist heat based disinfection method used to destroy food spoiling organisms in milk, thereby extending their shelf-life. It was found and described by Louis Pasteur . ( Options A and D ruled out ) There are three methods of pasteurisation: Holder’s method - Milk is heated at 63 o C for 30 minutes . It can kill all non-sporing pathogens such as Mycobacteria , Brucella and Salmonella . But Coxiella burnetti are more heat-resistant and hence not killed . Flash method - Milk is heated at 72 o C for 15-20 seconds followed by quickly cooling to 13 o C or lower . It can kill Coxiella species as well as organisms killed by Holder's method. Ultra-high-temperature method(UHT) - Here milk is heated at 149 o C for 1-2 seconds . Used as a quick method for large scale disinfection. Presence of the enzyme phosphatase in the milk post-treatment suggests inadequate efficacy (Option C): Phosphatase test is used to test the efficacy of pasteurisation as the process of pasteurisation destroys the enzyme phosphatase present in milk. If present after the process, then it indicates contamination or inadequate pasteurisation . Coliform test is another test used to check for efficacy of pasteurisation. Reference: . Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 30,36,635 2. Essentials of Medical Microbiology- Apurba S Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page 252, 259, 315

questions.question: Which of the following sterilisation/disinfection techniques acts on the principle of moist heat at 100 o C?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Tyndallization Explanation: Tyndallization is the sterilisation/disinfection technique that acts on the principle of moist heat at 100 o C.(BAT-boling at 100 is tyndallisation. Tyndallization is also called intermittent sterilisation . It involves exposure to moist heat at 100 o C for 20 minutes on three successive days . The first exposure kills all vegetative bacteria . Spores which survive the first heat treatment, are allowed to germinate in the favourable medium. Subsequent exposures kill the newly formed vegetative cells from the germinated spores . Mainly used for sterilising media containing sugars or gelatin like TCBS, XLD, DCA, Selenite F broth . And other culture media where traditional autoclaving may affect the composition. However, its limitations are that it may not effectively kill spores of certain anaerobic bacteria and thermophiles (heat-loving bacteria) may also survive. Inspissation (Option A): It is also a sterilisation technique using moist heat but at 80–85°C for 30 minutes on 3 successive days. It is used to sterilise egg containing and serum containing culture media such as Lowenstein–Jensen medium for Mycobacterium species and Loeffler’s serum slope for diphtheria respectively. Incineration (Option B): It is a sterilisation technique that uses dry heat at very high temperatures in the range of 870°C to 980°C. This is a safe method t o treat large solid infectious waste, particularly anatomical waste like amputated limbs, animal carcasses and chemical wastes such as expired medications and chemicals. It converts the material into ash, leaving about a tenth of the original volume . However, it is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. It is the safest method to ensure that no infective materials remain , including prions(infective proteins). Pasteurization (Option D) : It is an intermediate-level disinfection technique that uses moist heat at temperatures <100°C to prevent various milk-borne infections and increase the shelf life of milk and fruit juices. Reference: 1. Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 15th Edition, Page 45 2. Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 28, 31, 36, 659 3. Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page 259

questions.question: As an intern in the orthopaedic department, you have been tasked to deliver the surgical instruments planned for the operating theatre to the CSSD. What temperature settings are kept in the following sterilisation machine at the CSSD? CSSD - Central Sterile Supply Department

options.A: 121 o C for 15 minutes at 15 psi pressure
options.D: 80 o C for 20-30 minutes for 3 consecutive days

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 121 o C for 15 minutes at 15 psi pressure. Explanation: The given image is of an autoclave machine. The temperature settings kept in the machine for sterilisation are 121 o C for 15 minutes at 15 psi pressure . An autoclave is a sterilisation technique that uses moist heat at a temperature > 100 o C. The autoclave (steam steriliser) works on the principle of steam production under pressure . When this steam meets a cooler surface, it condenses, transferring its heat to that surface. The process continues until the surface temperature matches that of the steam. The resulting condensed water provides moist heat, effectively killing microbes on the materials by protein denaturation . Its temperature settings are 121 o C for 15 minutes at 15 psi

questions.question: Which of the following substances can be sterilised by membrane filters?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Antibiotic solution Explanation: Out of all the options, antibiotic solutions can be sterilised only by membrane filters. Membrane filtration is considered as one of the sterilisation techniques although only filtration of microorganisms occurs and not killing . Filtration is of mainly two types - membrane filtration and depth filtration . Membrane filtration is widely used in healthcare mainly in the filtration of air and water . Air filtration Water filtration It is done by using high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters designed to remove organisms larger than 0.3 µ m from isolation rooms, operating rooms , and biological safety cabinets (BSCs) . ULPA filters (Ultra-low particulate/penetration air) can remove from the air at least 99.9% of dust and any airborne particles with a size of 0.12 µ m or larger. Surgical (3-ply) masks and respirators are the simplest examples of filters being used for purification of air. They remove microorganisms based on their pore size. Used for bacteriological examination of water in hospital settings , especially dialysis water. Also used to remove bacteria from pharmaceutical fluids that are heat labile and cannot be purified by any other means e.g. sera , sugar, toxin , vaccine and antibiotic solutions . The sterilisation control of membrane filters are Brevundimonas diminuta and Serratia marcescens . Suture material (Option A): In general, all suture materials are sterilised by autoclave except catgut which is sterilised by ionising radiation .(cold sterilisation) Liquid paraffin (Option B) is sterilised by a hot air oven, not membrane filters. Plastic syringe (Option C): Ionizing radiation, such as gamma radiation, is used to sterilise plastic disposables such as plastic syringes, catheters, or gloves before use. Reference: 1. Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 15th Edition, Page 46 2. Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page 256, 257 3. Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 32-33

questions.question: What is the quality control agent used in the shown method of disinfection?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Bacillus pumilus Explanation: Shown method (in the image) is disinfection by Ultraviolet (UV) radiation . Quality control agent used for Radiation is Bacillus pumilus . Radiation: Ionising Features: High penetration power Sporicidal action + Known as Cold radiation (do not increase surface heat) Examples: Gamma rays, X-rays, Cosmic rays Uses: Plastics, syringes, catheters Catgut sutures - Gamma ( γ ) rays Non-ionising Features: Low penetration power Only bactericidal action + Examples: UV rays, infrared rays Uses: Plastics, syringes, catheters Mechanism of action DNA damage by Dimer formation Quality control agent Bacillus pumilus (Option C) Other options: Bacillus atrophaeus niger (Option A): used for Hot air oven Bacillus atrophaeus globigii (Option B): used for Ethylene oxide (Gas plasma) Geobacillus stearothermophilus (Option D): used for Autoclave Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/779652/ Ananthanarayan & Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition pages- 32,33,36. Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology by Mahon, Lehman 6th Edition pages- 61,62.

questions.question: What is the ideal agent of choice for sterilizing the shown instrument?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 2% Glutaraldehyde Explanation: Flexible endoscopes and Laryngoscopes (shown in the image) are categorized under semi-critical items in Spaulding's Classification . Aldehydes are the preferred agents for sterilization of semi-critical items. Spaulding’s classification of medical devices is used to classify medical devices into three categories according to the degree of risk for infection according to their use and the subsequent level of reprocessing required to render the devices safe for reuse . Risk category Recommended method Medical device/Equipment 1. Critical device (high risk): Items that enter a normally sterile site . Sterilisation If heat resistant : Hot air oven or autoclave If heat-sensitive : Ionising radiation or ethylene oxide or plasma sterilisation. Surgical instruments , implants /prostheses, rigid endoscopes , syringes, needles, CuT, Urinary catheter 2. Semi-critical device (intermediate risk): Items in contact with mucous membranes or body fluids . High-level disinfection (HLD) : Such as glutaraldehyde , ortho-phthalaldehyde, formaldehyde and hydrogen peroxide . Respiratory equipment , non-invasive flexible endoscopes, bedpans , urine bottles 3. Non-critical (low-risk) Items in contact with intact skin. Intermediate or Low-level disinfection (ILD or LLD): Such as phenols , chlorhexidine, isopropyl alcohol , povidone-iodine , etc Patient items include blood pressure cuffs , ECG electrodes, thermometer and stethoscopes . Environmental surfaces include computers, bed rails , food utensils, bedside tables , patient furniture and floor. Aldehydes: Examples 2% Glutaraldehyde (Option A) : Activated by alkalinisation 0.55% Orthophthaldehyde: More stable, more active Formaldehyde Mechanism of action Alkylation + DNA damage by cross linking Uses [ Semi-critical: in contact with mucous membrane] Flexible endoscopes, Laryngoscope (Option A) , Vaginal speculum, Anesthetic equipment. Specific uses:

questions.question: What is the mechanism of action of the most commonly used oral antiseptic?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Protein denaturation Explanation: The most commonly used oral antiseptic is Chlorhexidine, a type of Phenol that causes protein Denaturation and membrane damage, leading to bactericidal action. Phenols: Examples Cresol: Rideal-walker coefficient- 10 , Stools disinfectant Lysol: Hospital disinfectant Chloroxylenol: Less action against Pseudomonas Chlorhexidine: non-toxic Mechanism of action Membrane damage + Protein denaturation (Option D) Uses Skin antiseptics, wound dressing Hospital floors and surroundings disinfectant Chlorhexidine: Oral antiseptic Halogens: Examples Tincture Iodine (2% Iodine): bactericidal + sporicidal Povidone Iodine (Betadine): has residual action Sodium hypochlorite (5.25%): Both bactericidal + virucidal Mechanism of action Oxidisation (Option A) Uses Skin antiseptic, wound dressing (Betadine preferred) Town water supply, Swimming pools (Chlorine) Sodium hypochlorite: Blood spills (1:10/1:100 dilution of 5.25% solution used) DNA dimers formation (Option B): MOA in Radiation sterilisation Alkylation (Option C): MOA in Gas sterilisation Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition page- 34.

questions.question: Which among the following is NOT true regarding Gas sterilisation?

options.A: Mechanism of bactericidal action is Alkylation
options.C: Refers to Ethylene oxide ideally used at 55-60°C for 4-12 hours
options.D: Suitable for fumigation of OT complexes

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Suitable for fumigation of OT complexes Explanation: Ethylene oxide is the most commonly used gas steriliser. Due to its explosive nature, it is NOT suitable for fumigating OT complexes. Gas sterilisation: Most commonly used Ethylene oxide (ETO) Concentration 450-700 mg ETO at 55-60°C for 4-12 hours (Option C) Mechanism of action Alkylation of DNA (Option A) and associated microbial proteins Uses Cardio-pulmonary (Heart-Lung) machine (Option B) , Respirators [ Critical class under Spaulding’s classification] Disadvantages Irritant: workers must use protective wears while using Explosive & Inflammable: Not suitable for fumigation (Option D) Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th Edition page- 34. Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology by Mahon, Lehman 6th Edition page- 66. Murray’s Medical Microbiology 8th Edition page- 11.

questions.question: What is the ideal agent of choice for managing blood spill from a fall of 5 mL vacutainer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1:100 dilution 5.25% Sodium hypochlorite Explanation: Small blood spillage (<10 mL) should be managed by 1:100 dilution of 5.25% Sodium hypochlorite after cleaning the area with an absorbable material. Blood spills management: Block off the area to be disinfected. Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves. Use brush and tongs to clean up broken glass pieces (never use bare hands) and discard the pieces onto a Sharps container (White). Use an absorbable material (paper/gauze/cloth) to wipe off body fluids/blood. Saturate the area with Sodium hypochlorite: Dose: 5.25% Sodium hypochlorite (Option D) Strength: Small spills (<10 mL) - 1:100 (Option D) , Large spills (>10 mL) - 1:10 dilution Rinse off the instruments used with running water and place to dry, discard absorbable material into the yellow bin. Remove and discard gloves into the red bin. Wash hands carefully with soap and water and dry using single-use towels. Record the incidence in the register.

questions.question: Which among the following tests gives a real-time assessment of microbiological contamination of a disinfectant in use?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Kelsey-Maurer test Explanation: Real-time assessment of microbiological contamination is done using the Kelsey-Maurer test . Testing of disinfectants: Rideal-Walker test Also known as the Phenol coefficient test . Tests the efficacy of a phenolic disinfectants (Lysol, Cresol) to kill Salmonella Typhi. Coefficient > 1 signifies that the disinfectant is efficacious. Disadvantage: Efficacy of organic matter is unknown Chick Martin test Modification of the Rideal-Walker test Tests the efficacy of phenolic disinfectant in presence of organic matter. Kelsey-Sykes test Tests the capacity of disinfectant to retain its activity with increasing microbiological load when used repeatedly. Kelsey-Maurer test Real-time assessment of microbiological contamination of in-use disinfectants in hospital Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology by Apurba S Sastry 3rd Edition page- 261.

questions.question: A chronic smoker with persistent cough was found to have a lung mass on imaging. A bronchoscope was used to obtain a lung biopsy. Based on the Spaulding classification, what category does this medical device fall under, and what is the appropriate sterilisation or disinfection agent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Semi-critical device and Glutaraldehyde Explanation: According to Spaulding’s classification of medical devices, the bronchoscope comes under semi-critical medical devices and it requires high-level disinfectants such as glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde and formaldehyde. Sterilisation If heat resistant : Hot air oven or autoclave If heat sensitive : Ionising radiation or ethylene oxide or plasma sterilisation. Surgical instruments , implants /prosthesis, rigid endoscopes , syringes, needles, CuT, Urinary catheter 2. questions.question: To which group of disinfectants does the commonly used cetrimide solution belong to?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Surface acting agents Explanation: Cetrimide is chemically acetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide which is classified under the group of surface acting agents of disinfectants. (Options A, B and D are ruled out) Surface-active agents are substances that act on the phosphate group of cell membranes by reducing the surface tension . After entering the cell, protein denaturation occurs. They act on bacteria, but have no action on spores , tubercle bacilli and most viruses . They are widely used as wetting agents, detergents and emulsifiers. The common compounds are acetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (Cetavlon or Cetrimide ) and benzalkonium chloride . These are most active at alkaline pH and acid inactivates them. Organic matter reduces their action and anionic surface-active agents, like ordinary soaps, render them inactive. Soaps prepared from saturated fatty acids (such as coconut oil) are more effective against Gram-negative bacilli, while those prepared from unsaturated fatty acids (oleic acid) have greater action against Gram-positive and the Neisseria group of organisms.
